title: How to Clean and Maintain a Trombone

steps.headline: Disassemble the trombone by unscrewing the bell portion from the slide and removing the mouthpiece.
Remove the outer slide and wipe off any excess grease, oil or moisture from the inner slides with a soft rag.
steps.description: Be careful not to bend or dent either slide in the process. Be gentle!

steps.headline: Use a cleaning rod or a “snake” (a flexible rubber coated metal wire with a small brush on both ends), clean out any excess grease, oil or moisture from the insides of the outer and inner slides.
steps.description: If using a cleaning rod, be careful not to jam the rod into the bottom of the slide. If you are rough, you risk denting the crook at the end of the slide.

steps.headline: Remove the main tuning slide from the bell portion and clean the inside with  a “snake”.
Do the same for F attachment tuning slide if your trombone has the F attachment.
If absolutely necessary, disassemble the rotary valve for the F attachment, rinse off each piece and wipe off excess oil or grease.
steps.description: However, this stage of the cleaning should really be handled by a trained instrument technician, as any sort of scratch or dent in the valve will adversely affect the playability of the horn.

steps.headline: Rinse all trombone components with warm water (NOT HOT, see warnings) in a shower or bath.
steps.description: Special attention should be given to the rotary valve, water key (or spit valve), and the outer and inner slides.

steps.headline: Dry off all components with a soft rag, making sure that no large pockets of water remain in any of the tubing or in the rotary valve.
Apply necessary grease to the tuning slides and attach them to the bell portion of the instrument.
Reassemble the rotary valve and apply necessary oils.
steps.description: Most of the oil should be applied by dripping it in through the pipe where the bell section and playing slide meet, though a few drops may be applied to the rotary valve directly.

steps.headline: Reassemble inner slide and outer slide and attach it to the bell section of the trombone.
Apply necessary slide grease or oils to the inner slide.
Wipe down the entire outside of the trombone using a soft rag.

tyn: Flexible brush commonly called a "snake" which can be purchased at any music store
Mouthpiece brush -- again available at any music store.
Mild soap. Some like to use horn soap (available at many music stores) but this is not necessary. Mild dish soap will be fine.  Lemon or orange is even better.
Some cotton rags (old t-shirts work best.)
Beach towel to dry the trombone
Two soft rags—one for the cleaning of the instrument, one for the polishing of the instrument after the cleaning is done
Cleaning rod and rag, or a “snake”
Any slide grease or oil that you normally use

Dry off all components with a soft rag, making sure that no large pockets of water remain in any of the tubing or in the rotary valve.  Apply necessary grease to the tuning slides and attach them to the bell portion of the instrument.  Reassemble the rotary valve and apply necessary oils. Most of the oil should be applied by dripping it in through the pipe where the bell section and playing slide meet, though a few drops may be applied to the rotary valve directly. Reassemble inner slide and outer slide and attach it to the bell section of the trombone.  Apply necessary slide grease or oils to the inner slide.  Wipe down the entire outside of the trombone using a soft rag.
